comment.narrative:
Only two islands have some reference to ISPs

No adaptation action has been implemented based on Island Strategic Plans

By the end of the project all outer islands have their ISPs revised to integrate climate risks

description.narrative: Marine based coastal livelihoods of Tuvaluan outer islands made resilient to declining productivity induced by climate variability and change

11 Households and communities have more secure access to livelihood assets disaggregated by gender AMAT 131
12 The area of Marine Protected Areas MPAs or Locally Managed Marine Areas LMMAs managed in a climateresilient manner
13 The level of awareness about links between improved marine ecosystem management and sustainability and resilience of subsistence marinebased livelihoods

comment.narrative:
Few households have access to traditional and resilient livelihood assets and methods Score2
Currently 76 km2 of island reef areas is under marine management includes Funafuti Conservation Area at 33km2 but currently no systematic management arrangement or resource monitoring framework is in place
Current understanding of the links between marine resource monitoring management and livelihoods is low

Score improved to 4 By the end of the project at least 50 of targeted outer islands households have access to climate resilient marinebased livelihood methods introducedstrengthened in the project genderdisaggregated data will be presented
The area of MPAMMAs is clarified and some form of management applied to at least a quarter of the reef area on each outer island area to be calculated with a corresponding climateresilient community management plan or Kaupule bylaw
Capacity to undertake creel surveys and maintain the database developed among communitybased MPAMMA management groups
At least 50 of Fisheries staff Kaupule women youth and fishers interviewed confirm a clear link between resource management and resilience of livelihoods genderdisaggregated data will be presented

In response to the 1st indicator This target has not been met as this is an ongoing activity at this moment There is an ongoing Knowledge Attitude and Practices KAP household survey activity disaggregated by gender that the project is implementing right now to assess and verify the amount of households and communities accessed climate resilient marinebased livelihoods
Score remains at 2 at this point in time
In response to the 2nd indicator There has been sharing of knowledge between PMU and Fiji Locally Managed Marine Area FLMMA 20 participants 3 from Tuvalu and the rest from Fiji with regards to the management of marine resources in Suva Fiji in May this year Lessons learned from this meeting were crucial as it helps the project plans smartly to engage communities to manage their marine resources in a climateresilient manner The outreach activity to the communities on the outer islands will be done in the third quarter depending on availability of vessels
In response to the 3rd indicator In April two workshops were conducted to increase awareness amongst responsible parties about the project and facilitate their active involvement Amongst the participants there were 22 men and 9 women
A Training of Facilitator activity was carried out in June and in this training participants were also taught about the importance of managing their marine resources sustainably for future generations Beneficial from this activity includes 34 men and 20 women and from these 54 participants one male participant is a person with disability

description.narrative: Resilience of island communities to climate change variability and risks is strengthened through participatory islandlevel planning budgeting and execution and communityled investments

Take up of climate resilient marinebased livelihood options
Percentage of the Tuvaluan population covered by the 247 early warning system
Outer island communities able to access climatedevelopment funds using climatemainstreamed ISPs

comment.narrative:
Traditional techniques that are resilient to changes in marine ecosystems have been lost or are not passed down by old people while access to new techniques materials and information from off island and overseas is poor These are limiting options for pursuing resilient appropriate and safe lowcost livelihoods
The existing communications systems are inadequate to send early warning message in a timely manner
No climate resilience investments made using the ISPs as a guiding tool

By the end of the Project at least 40 of the targeted households adopted at least one form of traditional resilient marine livelihood methods including canoe building traditional fishing methods postharvest fish processing or aquaculture genderdisaggregated data will be presented
95 of Tuvaluan receives early warning in a timely manner using one of the multiple communication lines genderdisaggregated data will be presented
By the end of the project at least eight adaptation priority actions one in each island at the island level outlined in ISPs are financed by either domestic or external resources and executed

This indicator has not been achieved
Onground activities on building resilience of marinebased livelihoods have not taken place Depending on the availability of a vessel traveling to outer islands it is expected that activities will start either in the last quarter of 2015 or first quarter of 2016
For work related to EWS preparatory work such as recruitment of a Telecommunication and EWS Expert has been done in order to expedite the procurement of all communications equipment to strengthen the existing communications systems
For islandlevel climate finance work this target will be completed once the CPEIR activity has been carried out and also ISPs have been revised to incorporate climate change actions
